attributes.title: PSC775 UNLV
attributes.description: This project is for PSC775 at UNLV in Spring 2020. This project includes five different experiments that will implement on MTurk.

q2.value: The purpose of this study is to explore how people process information in the political domain. It is composed of several parts. Part I focuses on the measurement of political knowledge. Part II focuses on how much people care the social welfare policy and the ongoing coronavirus. Part III study the people’s attitude on immigration policy. Part IV focuses on how people feel the government’s response to natural disaster in the past. And Part V explores people’s interaction with others in politics.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value:
1. When the survey is posted on MTurk, only the respondents who are over 18 and have a 90% approval rating or higher for previous hits can participate in this survey.

2. All subjects will firstly be asked a series of general question regarding their political interest and their understanding of politics (e.g. who is the chairperson of House).  Q1-Q9

3. On Q10, all subjects will be randomly assigned into four groups: (a) whether they support a medical policy (b) whether they support if the policy is endorsed by Democrat Nancy Pelosi (c) whether they support if the policy is endorsed by Independent Bernie Sanders (d) whether they support if the policy is endorsed by Conservative Democrat Doug Jones
After Q10, all subjects are asked about their turnout in 2018 and 2020, and their party identification.

4. On Q14, all subjects will be randomly assigned into three group and asked (a) n/a (b) whether they concern the coronavirus globally (c) whether they concern the coronavirus in the U.S.. All subjects will then be asked their level of nationalism on Q15

5. On Q16, all subjects will be randomly assigned into six groups: 
(a) A study is currently being conducted that examines the integration of [Arab Americans]
into American society. The study shows that approximately [25%] of Arab Americans
speak Arabic at home.
To what extent do you think [name of group] as a whole is well-integrated into American society?   
(b) [Arab Americans] [75%]
(c) [Hispanic Americans] [75%]
(d) [Hispanic Americans] [75%]
(e) [minorities] [25%]
(f) [minorities] [75%]             (Since the numbers are fabricated, respondents will be debriefed at the end of survey)

6. On Q17-20, all respondents are asked to place themselves on ideological space, and their attitude toward redistribution

7. On Q21-24, all respondents are asked their experience of natural disaster before (property damage) and how they evaluate the government’s response.

8. On Q25-27, all subjects are randomly assigned into four groups. Group (a) and (b) are asked to evaluate how they feel the photo of two voters. Group (c) and (d) are asked whether they would like to interact with the voter in the photo.

9. On Q28-32, all subjects are randomly assigned into six groups. They are asked to interpret the poll number and transfer it into the chance of winning of candidates.

10. On Q33-Q40, all subjects are asked about their basic background, including gender, age, education, state, and county they live in.

11. After Q40, all subjects will then be debriefed about Q10 and Q16.

attributes.title: Predict affect using mobile sensor data
attributes.description: This project intends to study whether affect can be predicted by a selection of mobile sensing data.

q2.value:
1.	For a given person, increasing phone usage may predict increased negative affect.
2.	For a given person, low typing speed and long keystroke duration may predict negative affect, low valence, and low arousal.
3.	For a given person, passive usage (low typing proportion in one given duration) may predict negative affect and low valence, while active usage (high typing proportion) predict the opposite.
4.	For a given person, high physical activity may predict positive affect.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
The data have been collected by previous thesis author Erika Vanbaelen using two apps, ActiTrack (for mobile sensor data) and MobileQ (for affect surveys).
During the original data collection procedure, all participants were assigned to the same condition, under which they were instructed to install ActiTrack and MobileQ onto their phone, and to use them for a period of 15 days. The demographic information were collected at the beginning of the study. Otherwise, participants answered the pop-up surveys ten times a day at randomly assigned time, activated by a beep reminder.

q8.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

question.value:
The original study recruited participants mainly through university network and social media, at the University of Leuven (KU Leuven). During the initial trial, 230 responses were recorded expressing interest in participation. The 230 volunteers were further screened for eligibility. 116 people were excluded because of insufficient knowledge of Dutch, insufficient usage of mobile phones, or owning a phone that ActiTrack did not support yet. Then only 65 people had ActiTrack successfully installed. Besides, they also installed MobileQ for affect survey. Both apps were de-activated after the 15-day experiment period. By the end of data collection, participants were compensated with a maximum of €50 for the study. The exact amount was proportional to the completion of the data response, for example, €5 for every 10% of reported assessment moment. 
As of the end of original data collection, five participants did not answer the minimum required amount of regularly triggered emotion surveys (minimum being 30 surveys) hence were excluded. Hence, the effective sample size for the current research will be 60. Additional outlier analysis will be run on these 60 people.

q11.value: As described in the previous section, the number of participants qualified for the current study is 60 people.

question.value: Dependent variable will be affect changes, which will be calculated using scores self-reported at different response points. Affect scores collected include Valence, Arousal, Negative Affect (sub-items Angry, Anxiety, Sad, Stress, Fatigue were collected in the survey), and Positive Affect (sub-item Happy, Relaxed were collected in the survey).

Mixed-Model Regression will be the primary analysis method in this study. The original dataset has been transcribed into R as raw data. After cleansing the raw data, the analysis will calculate the parameters proposed to predict hypothesized affect changes that are not immediately available from the raw data. 
1.	Screen time: the sum of the screen-on time of 60 minutes before a beep.
2.	Typing speed: the number of typed characters divided by the typing duration. The mean typing speed will be calculated in 60 minutes before a beep.
3.	Phone usage: typing duration divided by screen time. The phone usage will be calculated in 60 minutes before a beep.

registration_responses.q2:
1.	For a given person, increasing phone usage may predict increased negative affect.
2.	For a given person, low typing speed and long keystroke duration may predict negative affect, low valence, and low arousal.
3.	For a given person, passive usage (low typing proportion in one given duration) may predict negative affect and low valence, while active usage (high typing proportion) predict the opposite.
4.	For a given person, high physical activity may predict positive affect.

q4: No blinding is involved in this study.

The demographic information were collected at the beginning of the study. Otherwise, participants answered the pop-up surveys ten times a day at randomly assigned time, activated by a beep reminder.
registration_responses.q10.question:
The original study recruited participants mainly through university network and social media, at the University of Leuven (KU Leuven). During the initial trial, 230 responses were recorded expressing interest in participation. The 230 volunteers were further screened for eligibility. 116 people were excluded because of insufficient knowledge of Dutch, insufficient usage of mobile phones, or owning a phone that ActiTrack did not support yet. Then only 65 people had ActiTrack successfully installed. Besides, they also installed MobileQ for affect survey. Both apps were de-activated after the 15-day experiment period. By the end of data collection, participants were compensated with a maximum of €50 for the study. The exact amount was proportional to the completion of the data response, for example, €5 for every 10% of reported assessment moment. 
As of the end of original data collection, five participants did not answer the minimum required amount of regularly triggered emotion surveys (minimum being 30 surveys) hence were excluded. Hence, the effective sample size for the current research will be 60. Additional outlier analysis will be run on these 60 people.
registration_responses.q15.question: Dependent variable will be affect changes, which will be calculated using scores self-reported at different response points. Affect scores collected include Valence, Arousal, Negative Affect (sub-items Angry, Anxiety, Sad, Stress, Fatigue were collected in the survey), and Positive Affect (sub-item Happy, Relaxed were collected in the survey).
registration_responses.q17.question:
Mixed-Model Regression will be the primary analysis method in this study. The original dataset has been transcribed into R as raw data. After cleansing the raw data, the analysis will calculate the parameters proposed to predict hypothesized affect changes that are not immediately available from the raw data. 
1.	Screen time: the sum of the screen-on time of 60 minutes before a beep.
2.	Typing speed: the number of typed characters divided by the typing duration. The mean typing speed will be calculated in 60 minutes before a beep.
3.	Phone usage: typing duration divided by screen time. The phone usage will be calculated in 60 minutes before a beep.

attributes.title: Proportional assist ventilation versus pressure support ventilation for weaning from mechanical ventilation in adults: Systemic Review and Meta-analysis
attributes.description:
Recently, numerous studies have compared PAV to traditional PSV, however, the data on the topic are still limited. Previous meta-analysis has conducted in the evidence of clinical use for PAV, but analysis of weaning outcomes for PAV is still insufficient to make specific recommendations. 
Therefore, we conducted a more comprehensive meta-analysis with state-of-the-art statistical methods to apply trial sequential analysis (TSA) to determine whether current included studies are conclusive and prevent premature conclusions from meta-analyses. The aim is to give an overview of comparison of PAV and PSV as an SBT to facilitate liberation from mechanical ventilation, and provide clinical recommendations to physicians in daily practice.

q1.value: Liang Jun, Ou Yang, Po-Huang Chen, Hong-Jie Jhou, Cho-Hao Lee

q2.value: This meta-analysis to assess the efficacy of the technique with the aim of providing treatment recommendations to physicians in daily clinical practice.

q3.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: Meta-analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

q8.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

question.value: We searched PubMed, Embase, and Cochrane Library to identify all relevant trials with screening the titles and reviewing the abstracts without filters or language restrictions. In order to ensure that no RCTs were missing, conference abstract and reference lists of included articles were reviewed. Further ongoing trials were searched using Google Scholar, the US government clinical trials database (www.ClinicalTrials.gov) and the UK National Research Register.

q11.value: The remaining 7 studies including 634 patients (6 two-arm studies, 1 three-arm study) were all included into our quantitative analysis.

question.value: The following outcomes were extracted: (1) major outcomes: weaning success, deﬁned as the absence of the requirement for invasive MV support, without reintubation, no cardiac arrest event or mortality for 48 hours after extubation (translaryngeal tube) or withdrawal (tracheostomy tube); (2) minor outcomes: proportion requiring reintubation (defined as the patient requiring reintubation in 48 hours after extubation), mortality (hospital mortality), intensive care unit (ICU) length of stay (the time from randomization to ICU discharge), duration of weaning (the time from randomization to extubation), and total duration of MV.

We conducted data analysis as recommended in the Cochrane Handbook for Systematic Reviews of Interventions. We calculated dichotomous outcomes by conducting random-effects meta-analysis proposed by DerSimonian and Laird and the Mantel-Haenszel fixed-effects model using risk ratio (RR) with 95% confidence interval (CI). To measure continuous outcomes, we employed the generic inverse variance method fixed-effect model and DerSimonian-Laird random-effects model meta-analysis using the mean difference (MD) approach with 95% CIs. 
	Heterogeneity was evaluated using the I square (I2) statistic and Cochran's Q test. Statistically significant heterogeneity was defined as I2 > 50% and Cochran's Q test P < 0.1. The presence of publication bias was assessed via funnel plots and with the Egger’s test.
In major outcome of weaning success, we further conducted subgroup analysis by the type of different proportional modes, PAV and PAV+, examined the difference of outcomes between these subgroups with test of interaction. 
We used a mixed-effects linear meta-regression model to evaluate the cause of heterogeneity for all outcomes, with variables including mean age, sex, baseline duration of MV and physiology score. Sensitivity analyses were conducted by excluding the trials with high RoB to the validity of study ﬁndings. Subgroup analyses were also done to investigate clinical or statistically heterogeneity based on interested variates. 
	All statistical analyses were performed using the “metafor” and “meta” packages of R software version 3.6.1. A p value of <0.05 was taken to indicate statistical signiﬁcance.

Trial sequential analysis
     Sparse data and repetitive testing of accumulating data in meta-analyses can producing an increased risk of random error, both type 1 and type 2. Therefore, a trial sequential analysis (TSA) was conducted to challenge the meta-analysis in case the data was too sparse to confirm the conclusion. TSA in meta-analysis is analogous to interim analyses in a single trial. TSA depends on the quantification of the required information size (the meta-analysis sample size). Required information size is estimated using a conventional sample size calculation and incorporating an estimate for diversity (D2). We constructed trial sequential analysis boundaries, according to the O’Brien-Fleming alpha-spending function, to assess whether the P value is statistically significant enough to show the anticipated effect or whether the analysis should be early-termination.
     Required information size allowing for a type 1 error and a type 2 error was set as 0.05 and 0.20, respectively. Relative risk reduction was assumed as 10%. The event rate in the control group was calculated from the mean of event proportions in all the trials. We provide the 95% confidence intervals adjusted for sparse data and repetitive testing, described as the TSA adjusted 95% confidence intervals. Random effect TSA was performed using trial sequential analysis software (version 0.9 Copenhagen Trial Unit, Copenhagen, Denmark).

attributes.title: The Use of 3D Visualization Techniques for Prostate Procedures: a Systematic  Review
attributes.description: Three-dimensional (3D) visualization technique has been reported as early as 20 years ago but is only recently applied so extensively in the medical field, due to price reduction and the rapid development of imaging reconstruction techniques. Virtual reality (VR) and augmented reality (AR) techniques, developed based on the 3D reconstruction of imaging data, can further enhance the impact of real-time imaging guidance during surgery with more realistic and accurate anatomic insights and tumor localization. In this study, we aim to systematically review the studies published by far and present the development and current application of 3D printing, VR, and AR technologies for the management of prostate cancer, specifically prostate biopsy (Bx) and radical prostatectomy (RP).

q1.value: Shu Wang, James Frisbie, Zachery Keepers, Zachary Bolten, Anjana Hevaganinge, Emad Boctor, Simon Leonard, Junichi Tokuda, Axel Krieger, Mohummad Minhaj Siddiqui

q2.value: In this review, we aim to present the development and current application of 3D printing, virtual reality (VR), and augmented reality (AR) techniques for prostate procedures, specifically prostate biopsy (Bx) and radical prostatectomy (RP).

q3.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
A systematic review of the literature will be performed following the guideline from the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analysis (PRISMA). PubMed, Scopus, and Embase will be screened for studies on the use of 3D printing, VR, and AR techniques in prostate Bx and RP, using the search query (3D printing OR virtual reality OR augmented reality) AND (prostate biopsy OR prostatectomy). All studies reporting outcomes of interest will be collected. Meeting abstracts, commentaries, editorials, reviews, and book chapters will be excluded. Two investigators (SW and JF) will independently screen all articles using the above criteria, and any disagreements on eligibility will be resolved by discussion between the two investigators until consensus is reached. 
Extracted data includes: Author; Publication Year; Journal; 3D imaging acquisition; Type of technique (3D, VR, or AR); Simulator/ patient; Procedure (Laparoscopic or Robotic assisted); Application (Education/Training Surgical planning, or Intra-op guidance). Two reviewers independently extract the data onto a pre-made excel sheet.

attributes.title: Asian Australian perspectives on coronavirus-related discrimination
attributes.description: The proposed project aims to investigate the link between coronavirus-related discrimination and psychological distress in Asian Australians. I propose that Asian Australians have perceived a rise in their experience of racial discrimination after the coronavirus outbreak compared to before it. I also propose that post-coronavirus discrimination predicts greater psychological distress in Asian Australians, which can be explained by greater anticipated discrimination.
attributes.withdrawal_justification: A decision was made to change some of the measurement scales before launching the study.

attributes.title: Do teachers' beliefs about science predict how they talk about scientists?

q1.value: Do teachers' beliefs about science predict how they talk about scientists?

q2.value: Michelle Momo Wang, Marjorie Rhodes, Amanda Cardarelli

q3.value:
Previous research has shown that the way science is described to children affects children's interest, persistence, and self-efficacy in science. For example, children who hear more action-based descriptions of science (e.g., "do science") from their teachers persist more on science engagement tasks, while children who hear more identity-references to scientists (e.g., "be scientists") from their teachers persist less on these tasks. In addition, children who hear more identity-references to scientists from their teachers also indicate less interest in science.

Given the direct effects of teachers' language on children's science learning, we hope to better understand what affects teachers' language and also how their language might affect children's beliefs about and interest in science across the pre-K school year. 

In this study, we research two imperative questions about teachers' language when describing science: 1) Do teachers' beliefs about science predict the language they use when teaching science (i.e., action-based descriptions of science or identity-references to scientists)? 2 ) Does teachers' language when teaching science affect children's beliefs about and interest in science?

Please refer to the "Study design" and "Hypotheses" section for a detailed description of the study procedure and a full list of research questions.

q4.value:
First, we predict that teachers will believe that being a top scientist requires more innate brilliance than being a typical scientist. Furthermore, we also predict that the more teachers believe that a top scientist requires more innate brilliance than a typical scientist, the more identity-references to scientists and the fewer action-based descriptions of science they will produce.

Second, we predict that the more teachers essentialize science, the more identity-references to scientists and the fewer action-based descriptions of science they will produce. Furthermore, we also predict that teachers' science essentialism scores will be positively correlated with how much more they believe being a top scientist requires innate brilliance than being a typical scientist.

Third, we predict that teachers' explicit science attitudes (e.g., how much they think boys are more naturally talented in science than girls) will be positively correlated with the number of identity-references to scientists and negatively correlated with the number of action-based descriptions of science they produce. Furthermore, we also predict that their explicit science attitudes will be positively correlated with their science essentialism scores and how much more they believe being a top scientist requires innate brilliance than being a typical scientist.

Fourth, we predict that the number of identity-references to scientists teachers produce will be negatively associated with children's inclusivity beliefs about science, including whom they think can do science/be a scientist, whom they think can observe, and whether they associate the big and small groups of people with science. Furthermore, we also predict that the number of action-based descriptions of science teachers produce will be positively associated with children's inclusivity beliefs about science, including whom they think can do science/be a scientist, whom they think can observe, and whether they associate the big and small groups of people with science. Also, we predict that teachers' beliefs about science (including their brilliance beliefs about top/typical scientists, their science essentialism scores, and their explicit science attitudes) will be negatively associated with children's inclusivity beliefs about science, including whom they think can do science/be a scientist, whom they think can observe, and whether they associate the big and small groups of people with science. Given previous work with older children that show how girls are more negatively affected than boys by identity-references to scientists, we also plan to test if the effects of language on children's inclusivity views about science might vary by participant gender (i.e, if girls' inclusivity views about science are both more negatively affected by identity-references to scientists and more positively affected by action-based descriptions of science) and how such interactive effects might develop across time during the Pre-K year.

Fifth, we predict that the number of identity-references to scientists teachers produce will be negatively associated with children's gender beliefs about science, including the number of girls they associate with science and the number of boys they associate with art. Furthermore, we also predict that the number of action-based descriptions of science teachers produce will be positively associated with children's gender beliefs about science, including the number of girls they associate with science and the number of boys they associate with art. Also, we predict that teachers' beliefs about science (including their brilliance beliefs about top/typical scientists, their science essentialism scores, and their explicit science attitudes) will be negatively associated with children's gender beliefs about science, including the number of girls they associate with science and the number of boys they associate with art. Given previous work with older children that show how girls are more negatively affected than boys by identity-references to scientists, we also plan to test if the effects of language on children's gender views about science might vary by participant gender (i.e, if girls' gender views about science are both more negatively affected by identity-references to scientists and more positively affected by action-based descriptions of science) and how such interactive effects might develop across time during the Pre-K year.

Sixth, we predict that the number of identity-references to scientists teachers produce will be negatively associated with children's interest in science, including their self-reported interest in science and their choice of reading a science book. Furthermore, we also predict that the number of action-based descriptions of science teachers produce will be positively associated with children's interest in science, including their self-reported interest in science and their choice of reading a science book. Also, we predict that teachers' beliefs about science (including their brilliance beliefs about top/typical scientists, their science essentialism scores, and their explicit science attitudes) will be negatively associated with children's interest in science, including their self-reported interest in science and their choice of reading a science book. Given previous work with older children that show how girls are more negatively affected than boys by identity-references to scientists, we also plan to test if the effects of language on children's interest in science might vary by participant gender (i.e, if girls' interest in science are both more negatively affected by identity-references to scientists and more positively affected by action-based descriptions of science) and how such interactive effects might develop across time during the Pre-K year.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
This is a study that is administered with the study "How do children develop the belief that only some people can be scientists?" (https://osf.io/wykre). Please refer to the above pre-registration for additional information.

First, we will send 186 pre-K teachers from a total of 52 sites across New York City a survey assessing their beliefs about science in January 2020. Specifically, we will ask them questions about how much innate brilliance a top and typical scientist respectively require (8 items total; 4 items for each type of scientist, order randomized), how much they essentialize science (6 items), and their explicit science attitudes (4 items). At the end of the survey, we will also ask them for their demographic information, including their age, gender, ethnicity, political beliefs, and level of education, and debrief them. Please refer to the "Teacher Beliefs Email" document for the email we send them that explains the survey and the "Teacher Science Beliefs Survey" for the Qualtrics file of the survey.

Then, we will send teachers a lesson plan about science (please refer to the "Mystery Capsules Lesson Plan" document) and a letter accompanying the lesson plan (please refer to the "Letter to go with lesson plan" document) sometime later in Spring 2020. In the letter, we will ask the pre-K teachers to deliver a lesson about the scientific method to their class and to audio record the class as they teach it. We will later code the audio recordings for teachers' use of the words "science" (including both as a noun and as an action) and "scientist" (including both identity-focused uses and generic uses; please refer to the "Teacher Language Coding Guide" document for specific coding guidelines of the audio recordings). 

During the 2019-2020 pre-K school year, the children from these participating teachers' classes will also be participating in our study "How do children develop the belief that only some people can be scientists?", in which their beliefs about and interest in science will also be assessed. Please refer to the pre-registration of this study (https://osf.io/wykre) for more information.

question.value: We recruited 186 teachers from 52 pre-K sites across 13 districts in New York City. Among the 186 participating teachers, 96 teachers participated in a similar study last year titled "Let's do Science! A randomized controlled trial to test if action-focused language increases science learning and engagement in Pre-K" (https://osf.io/pe7k5/). Among the 96 teachers who participated last year, 54 were in the science language intervention condition while the other 42 were in the control condition (please refer to the above registration). We have assured that teachers who participated last year will be assigned the same anonymous ID this year so that their data can be compared to that of last year. Teachers will not be compensated directly or individually, but participating sites will receive a gift card that amounts to a $10 compensation per participating teacher, which they can spend however they want.

q13.value: Our sample size is currently 186 teachers from 52 pre-K sites across 13 districts, although the exact sample size might change slightly if more teachers agree to participate or decide to drop out. Given previous research with a similar population, we expect teacher participation and success of audio recording to be high (at least 90%).

q14.value: We determined this sample size based on the number of pre-K sites and teachers we were able to recruit.

q15.value: We will stop data collection once we test all the teachers in our expected sample.

For other variables related to children's beliefs about and interest in science, please refer to the pre-registration for the study "How do children develop the belief that only some people can be scientists?" (https://osf.io/wykre).

1. Teachers' brilliance beliefs about a top/typical scientist
Participants' responses across the four items for each type of scientist will be averaged (their responses for items 3 and 4 will be reverse-coded) and their scores for a typical scientist will be subtracted from their scores for a top scientist to determine how much more they believe innate brilliance is required from the latter than the former

Participants' responses across the six items will be averaged

Participants' responses across the four items will be averaged

In addition, children who hear more identity-references to scientists from their teachers also indicate less interest in science.

Given the direct effects of teachers' language on children's science learning, we hope to better understand what affects teachers' language and also how their language might affect children's beliefs about and interest in science across the pre-K school year. 

In this study, we research two imperative questions about teachers' language when describing science: 1) Do teachers' beliefs about science predict the language they use when teaching science (i.e., action-based descriptions of science or identity-references to scientists)? 2 ) Does teachers' language when teaching science affect children's beliefs about and interest in science?

Please refer to the "Study design" and "Hypotheses" section for a detailed description of the study procedure and a full list of research questions.
registration_responses.q4:
First, we predict that teachers will believe that being a top scientist requires more innate brilliance than being a typical scientist. Furthermore, we also predict that the more teachers believe that a top scientist requires more innate brilliance than a typical scientist, the more identity-references to scientists and the fewer action-based descriptions of science they will produce.

Second, we predict that the more teachers essentialize science, the more identity-references to scientists and the fewer action-based descriptions of science they will produce. Furthermore, we also predict that teachers' science essentialism scores will be positively correlated with how much more they believe being a top scientist requires innate brilliance than being a typical scientist.

Third, we predict that teachers' explicit science attitudes (e.g., how much they think boys are more naturally talented in science than girls) will be positively correlated with the number of identity-references to scientists and negatively correlated with the number of action-based descriptions of science they produce. Furthermore, we also predict that their explicit science attitudes will be positively correlated with their science essentialism scores and how much more they believe being a top scientist requires innate brilliance than being a typical scientist.

Fourth, we predict that the number of identity-references to scientists teachers produce will be negatively associated with children's inclusivity beliefs about science, including whom they think can do science/be a scientist, whom they think can observe, and whether they associate the big and small groups of people with science. Furthermore, we also predict that the number of action-based descriptions of science teachers produce will be positively associated with children's inclusivity beliefs about science, including whom they think can do science/be a scientist, whom they think can observe, and whether they associate the big and small groups of people with science. Also, we predict that teachers' beliefs about science (including their brilliance beliefs about top/typical scientists, their science essentialism scores, and their explicit science attitudes) will be negatively associated with children's inclusivity beliefs about science, including whom they think can do science/be a scientist, whom they think can observe, and whether they associate the big and small groups of people with science. Given previous work with older children that show how girls are more negatively affected than boys by identity-references to scientists, we also plan to test if the effects of language on children's inclusivity views about science might vary by participant gender (i.e, if girls' inclusivity views about science are both more negatively affected by identity-references to scientists and more positively affected by action-based descriptions of science) and how such interactive effects might develop across time during the Pre-K year.

Fifth, we predict that the number of identity-references to scientists teachers produce will be negatively associated with children's gender beliefs about science, including the number of girls they associate with science and the number of boys they associate with art. Furthermore, we also predict that the number of action-based descriptions of science teachers produce will be positively associated with children's gender beliefs about science, including the number of girls they associate with science and the number of boys they associate with art. Also, we predict that teachers' beliefs about science (including their brilliance beliefs about top/typical scientists, their science essentialism scores, and their explicit science attitudes) will be negatively associated with children's gender beliefs about science, including the number of girls they associate with science and the number of boys they associate with art. Given previous work with older children that show how girls are more negatively affected than boys by identity-references to scientists, we also plan to test if the effects of language on children's gender views about science might vary by participant gender (i.e, if girls' gender views about science are both more negatively affected by identity-references to scientists and more positively affected by action-based descriptions of science) and how such interactive effects might develop across time during the Pre-K year.

Sixth, we predict that the number of identity-references to scientists teachers produce will be negatively associated with children's interest in science, including their self-reported interest in science and their choice of reading a science book. Furthermore, we also predict that the number of action-based descriptions of science teachers produce will be positively associated with children's interest in science, including their self-reported interest in science and their choice of reading a science book. Also, we predict that teachers' beliefs about science (including their brilliance beliefs about top/typical scientists, their science essentialism scores, and their explicit science attitudes) will be negatively associated with children's interest in science, including their self-reported interest in science and their choice of reading a science book. Given previous work with older children that show how girls are more negatively affected than boys by identity-references to scientists, we also plan to test if the effects of language on children's interest in science might vary by participant gender (i.e, if girls' interest in science are both more negatively affected by identity-references to scientists and more positively affected by action-based descriptions of science) and how such interactive effects might develop across time during the Pre-K year.

registration_responses.q8.question:
This is a study that is administered with the study "How do children develop the belief that only some people can be scientists?" (https://osf.io/wykre). Please refer to the above pre-registration for additional information.

First, we will send 186 pre-K teachers from a total of 52 sites across New York City a survey assessing their beliefs about science in January 2020. Specifically, we will ask them questions about how much innate brilliance a top and typical scientist respectively require (8 items total; 4 items for each type of scientist, order randomized), how much they essentialize science (6 items), and their explicit science attitudes (4 items). At the end of the survey, we will also ask them for their demographic information, including their age, gender, ethnicity, political beliefs, and level of education, and debrief them. Please refer to the "Teacher Beliefs Email" document for the email we send them that explains the survey and the "Teacher Science Beliefs Survey" for the Qualtrics file of the survey.

Then, we will send teachers a lesson plan about science (please refer to the "Mystery Capsules Lesson Plan" document) and a letter accompanying the lesson plan (please refer to the "Letter to go with lesson plan" document) sometime later in Spring 2020. In the letter, we will ask the pre-K teachers to deliver a lesson about the scientific method to their class and to audio record the class as they teach it. We will later code the audio recordings for teachers' use of the words "science" (including both as a noun and as an action) and "scientist" (including both identity-focused uses and generic uses; please refer to the "Teacher Language Coding Guide" document for specific coding guidelines of the audio recordings). 

During the 2019-2020 pre-K school year, the children from these participating teachers' classes will also be participating in our study "How do children develop the belief that only some people can be scientists?", in which their beliefs about and interest in science will also be assessed. Please refer to the pre-registration of this study (https://osf.io/wykre) for more information.

q8.uploader.file_name: Letter to go with lesson plan.docx

registration_responses.q12.question: We recruited 186 teachers from 52 pre-K sites across 13 districts in New York City. Among the 186 participating teachers, 96 teachers participated in a similar study last year titled "Let's do Science! A randomized controlled trial to test if action-focused language increases science learning and engagement in Pre-K" (https://osf.io/pe7k5/). Among the 96 teachers who participated last year, 54 were in the science language intervention condition while the other 42 were in the control condition (please refer to the above registration). We have assured that teachers who participated last year will be assigned the same anonymous ID this year so that their data can be compared to that of last year. Teachers will not be compensated directly or individually, but participating sites will receive a gift card that amounts to a $10 compensation per participating teacher, which they can spend however they want.

attributes.title: The effectiveness of stress regulation interventions with athletes: Systematic review and meta-analysis of randomised controlled trials
attributes.description: Existing stress-regulation interventions in the sporting field target components of the stress process including: stressors (i.e., a demanding or challenging event that elicits a stress response; see Kerr & Goss, 1996), appraisals (i.e., cognitive evaluation of the potential of the situation to cause harm to functioning; see Larsson, Cook, & Starrin, 1988), affective responses (i.e., the emotional state of an individual following an event; see Wojcikiewicz & Orlick, 1987), and/or coping efforts put in place (i.e., cognitive and behavioural efforts to manage stressors; see Haney, 2004). Cognitive (e.g., thought appraisal, self-talk), multimodal (e.g., cognitive and somatic relaxation training), and alternative (e.g., anger awareness, biofeedback) stress-regulation interventions appear promising for equipping athletes with the knowledge and skills to regulate their stressor experience effectively (Rumbold, Fletcher, & Daniels, 2012). However, our knowledge of the nature of the most effective stress regulation interventions for athletes is limited in several ways. First, an integrative understanding of the effectiveness of stress regulation interventions for athletes is limited to narrative literature reviews (e.g., Rumbold et al., 2012), rather than a statistical synthesis that can provide insight into the magnitude of effect and extent to which the effects generalise across contexts. Doing so requires that we leverage the findings of randomised controlled trials because they provide high-quality evidence regarding cause and effect. Second, the content and structure of effective stress regulation interventions is limited to broad descriptions of the nature of the program (e.g., appraisals, biofeedback). As such, there is a need to interrogate the descriptions of stress regulation interventions in ways that clarify the active ingredients and processes by which these strategies are delivered to athletes to inform guidelines for best practice. Third, the effectiveness of stress regulation interventions is equivocal, so there is a need to explore these differential effects by examining the specific components and outcome measures used in stress regulation experimental designs. We address these gaps in the literature in this systematic review and meta-analysis.

q2.value:
The aims of this systematic review and meta-analysis are to:
1.	Assess the effectiveness of stress regulation interventions on athletes’ performance and their perceptions of psychological stress. 
2.	Determine the conditions under which stress regulation interventions may differentially affect athletes’ performance and their perceptions of psychological stress. 
3.	Assess the nature of stress regulation interventions (e.g., content, delivery mode) that are found to optimise athletes’ performance and their perceptions of psychological stress.

q3.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Random-effects meta analysis.

The data 'exists' because it has been published, but we have not yet started the search and screen process.

q11.value: Uncertain as we are conducting a systematic review and meta-analysis.

question.value: Not applicable

As athletes engage in sport primarily to achieve valued performance outcomes, we focus on performance as the primary outcome for this systematic review and meta-analysis. Within sporting contexts, performance represents the enactment of behavioural or cognitive tasks that characterise assessments of success in one’s sporting domain. As such, we will consider indices of performance across technical, tactical, or physical domains (Janelle & Hillman, 2003). We expected individual performance will be assessed via objective (e.g., competition statistics), informant-reported (e.g., coach assessed), and/or subjective (i.e., self-reported) measures. Given the centrality of athlete appraisals within the stress regulation process (e.g., Hobfoll, 1989; Lazarus, 1999), we will also examine athletes’ stress perceptions as a secondary outcome. The transactional stress process consists of a wide variety of parts including stressors, appraisals, emotions, and coping; it is the balance of and interrelation among these components that has the potential to affect athletes’ perceptions of stress (Lazarus & Folkman, 1984). For completeness, we will include as secondary outcomes athletes’ perceptions across all components of the psychological stress process.

attributes.title: The Relationship Between Weight Stigma and Health Behaviors

q1.value: Relationship between Weight Stigma and Health Behaviors

q2.value: LEE, KRISTEN M, A. Janet Tomiyama, Jeffrey M Hunger

q4.value:
H1: We predict that individuals who experience greater weight stigma will report: greater disordered eating; higher frequency of comfort eating; greater sleep disturbance; greater alcohol use; and less physical activity. 

H2: We predict that weight status, as assessed by (1) BMI and (2) perceived weight, will moderate the effect of weight stigma on disordered eating, comfort eating, alcohol use, sleep disturbance, and physical activity, such that those with higher BMI/perceived weight will show a stronger relationship between weight stigma and these outcomes.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This is a cross-sectional survey study administered through the online survey platform, Qualtrics.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: We have selected  a random sample of 500 participants for exploratory analyses and now are registering confirmatory analyses on the remaining 1522 participants.

question.value: In order to collect a more nationally representative sample, we have obtained subjects through a Qualtrics panel. Subjects were U.S. Census matched using quotas for age, gender, race, income, and census region. Subjects are at least 18 years old and English-speaking. The data was collected in December 2019 and January 2020. Participants were compensated directly via Qualtrics.

q13.value: We have a total of 2,022 subjects who completed the study and passed the quality check via Qualtrics panel.

q14.value: Our target sample size was determined by the project directors, Jeffrey Hunger and A. Janet. Tomiyama. This number was the maximum number of participants that they could afford given currently available funds.

question.value:
Daily experiences with anticipated stigma and discrimination experiences regarding weight:
Questionnaires were developed based on Hunger & Major, 2015 and Williams et al., 1997. Participants report on a 4-point scale (Not at all – Often) indicating the frequency of experiencing and anticipating weight-related discrimination in day-to-day life. 
 
Body Mass Index: Body mass index (BMI) is the ratio of weight to height used to estimate body fat (Deurenberg et al., 1991). BMI scores will be calculated with the standard BMI formula of weight in pounds divided by height in inches squared x 703 using self-reported height (feet and inches) and weight measurements (pounds). 

Perceived weight status: Assessed using a one question item asking individuals to rate their weight status on a scale of a 1 (Very underweight) to 7 (Very overweight). 

Physical activity: As measured by the single item Stanford Leisure-Time Activity Categorical Item (L-CAT) (Kiernan et al., 2013) comprised of six activity categories ranging from inactive to very active; each category corresponds to an intensity level based on metabolic equivalents (METS).  Participants select the L-CAT category that best describes their physical activity over the past month.

Sleep disturbance: As measured by the six-item Sleep Disturbance form based on the Patient-Reported Outcomes Measurement Information System (PROMIS) item bank (Yu et al., 2011). Participants report sleep quality over the past week on a 5-point scale (Very Poor — Very Good) and frequency of sleep disturbance in the past week on a 5-point scale (Not at all — Very Much). 

Alcohol use: Alcohol use will be measured by the 3-item Alcohol Use Disorders Identification Test (AUDIT-C) (Bush et al., 1998). Participants report on quantity of drinks on a 6-point scale (0 — 10 or more drinks), frequency of drinking behavior in the past month (Never — 6 or more times a week) and frequency of drinking behavior in the past year on a five-point scale (Never — Daily or almost daily). Items will be scored on a scale of 0-4, and a total alcohol use score will be calculated by summing all three response items.
 
Disordered eating: As measured using the 12-item self-report Eating Disorder Examination Questionnaire (EDE-QS) (Gideon et al., 2016). Participants report on a four-point rating scale (0 - 7 days) and (Not at all - Markedly) in reference to behaviors, thoughts, feelings over the past 7 days (Gideon et al., 2016). Response values range from 0 – 3, with higher scores indicating higher symptoms.
 
Comfort eating: Comfort eating will be assessed using a one question item assessing frequency of comfort eating within the last 30 days. Participants indicate any number of days between 0 - 30 days as their response.

We will create a single composite measure of weight stigma by computing the mean of scores on the daily anticipated stigma and daily discrimination experiences questionnaires, given that the two measures were highly correlated (r= .77) in the exploratory analyses.

Hypothesis 1: Multivariate linear regression will be conducted.  The composite measure of weight stigma will be the predictor variable, and separate models will estimate the relationship between weight stigma and each of our outcome variables. All models will control for BMI. Hypothesis 2: We will use the PROCESS macro (Hayes, 2018; model #1) with BMI as the moderator for one model, and perceived weight as the moderator for another model, of the relationship between the weight stigma composite and the outcome variables, estimating separate models for each outcome variables.

q22.value: We will exclude participant data of respondents who did not pass the Qualtrics quality check screening or who provided an incorrect response for the attention check question. We will also exclude any participants who report implausible height (<44 inches or > 90 inches) or weight values (<55 pounds or > 1,000 pounds), or who have BMI scores that are less than 12 or greater than 70 (Cheng et al., 2016).

q24.value: H1: We will run exploratory gender moderation analyses with no directional hypotheses. We will use the PROCESS macro (Hayes, 2018; model #1) with gender as the moderator of the relationship between the weight stigma composite and the outcome variables (controlling for BMI), estimating separate models for each outcome variable.

attributes.title: Data From: Chromosome-level hybrid de novo genome assemblies as an attainable option for non-model insects
attributes.description: Best assembly of Drosophila mojavensis from the Sonora population.

summary.value: The emergence of third generation sequencing (3GS; long-reads) is making closer the goal of chromosome-size fragments in de novo genome assemblies. This allows the exploration of new and broader questions on genome evolution for a number of non-model organisms. However, long- read technologies result in higher sequencing error rates and therefore impose an elevated cost of sufficient coverage to achieve high enough quality. In this context, hybrid assemblies, combining short-reads and long-reads provide an alternative efficient and cost-effective approach to generate de novo, chromosome-level genome assemblies. The array of available software programs for hybrid genome assembly, sequence correction and manipulation are constantly being expanded and improved. This makes it difficult for non-experts to find efficient, fast and tractable computational solutions for genome assembly, especially in the case of non-model organisms lacking a reference genome or one from a closely related species. In this study, we review and test the most recent pipelines for hybrid assemblies, comparing the model organism Drosophila melanogaster to a non- model cactophilic Drosophila, D. mojavensis. We show that it is possible to achieve excellent contiguity on this non-model organism using the DBG2OLC pipeline.
